text: The vision of Isaiah son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, O heavens, and listen, O earth,
    for the Lord has spoken:
I reared children and brought them up,
    but they have rebelled against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ox knows its owner
    and the donkey its master’s crib,
but Israel does not know;
    my people do not understand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe, sinful nation,
    people laden with iniquity,
offspring who do evil,
    children who act corruptly,
who have forsaken the Lord,
    who have despised the Holy One of Israel,
    who are utterly estranged!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you seek further beatings?
    Why do you continue to rebel?
The whole head is injured,
    and the whole heart faint.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the sole of the foot to the head,
    there is no soundness in it,
only bruises and sores
    and bleeding wounds;
they have not been drained or bound up
    or softened with oil.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And daughter Zion is left
    like a booth in a vineyard,
like a shelter in a cucumber field,
    like a besieged city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the Lord of hosts
    had not left us a few survivors,
we would have been like Sodom
    and become like Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear the word of the Lord,
    you rulers of Sodom!
Listen to the teaching of our God,
    you people of Gomorrah!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When you come to appear before me,
    who asked this from your hand?
    Trample my courts no more!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bringing offerings is futile;
    incense is an abomination to me.
New moon and Sabbath and calling of convocation—
    I cannot endure solemn assemblies with iniquity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Come now, let us argue it out,
    says the Lord:
If your sins are like scarlet,
    will they become like snow?
If they are red like crimson,
    will they become like wool?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are willing and obedient,
    you shall eat the good of the land,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but if you refuse and rebel,
    you shall be devoured by the sword,
    for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the faithful city
    has become a prostitute!
    She that was full of justice,
righteousness lodged in her—
    but now murderers!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your silver has become dross;
    your wine is mixed with water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your princes are rebels
    and companions of thieves.
Everyone loves a bribe
    and runs after gifts.
They do not defend the orphan,
    and the widow’s cause does not come before them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore says the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel:
Surely I will pour out my wrath on my enemies
    and avenge myself on my foes!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And I will restore your judges as at the first
    and your counselors as at the beginning.
Afterward you shall be called the city of righteousness,
    the faithful city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion shall be redeemed by justice,
    and those in her who repent, by righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But rebels and sinners shall be destroyed together,
    and those who forsake the Lord shall be consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you shall be ashamed of the oaks
    in which you delighted,
and you shall blush for the gardens
    that you have chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you shall be like an oak
    whose leaf withers
    and like a garden without water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The strong shall become like tinder
    and their work like a spark;
they and their work shall burn together,
    with no one to quench them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In days to come
    the mountain of the Lord’s house
shall be established as the highest of the mountains
    and shall be raised above the hills;
all the nations shall stream to it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many peoples shall come and say,
“Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,
    to the house of the God of Jacob,
that he may teach us his ways
    and that we may walk in his paths.”
For out of Zion shall go forth instruction
    and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
O house of Jacob,
    come, let us walk
in the light of the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have forsaken your people,
    the house of Jacob,
for they are full of diviners from the East
    and of soothsayers like the Philistines,
    and they clasp hands with foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their land is filled with silver and gold,
    and there is no end to their treasures;
their land is filled with horses,
    and there is no end to their chariots.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And so people are humbled,
    and everyone is brought low—
    do not forgive them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Enter into the rock,
    and hide in the dust
from the terror of the Lord
    and from the glory of his majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The haughty eyes of people shall be brought low,
    and the pride of everyone shall be humbled,
and the Lord alone will be exalted on that day.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
against all the high mountains
    and against all the lofty hills;
speaker: Narrator

text:
against every high tower
    and against every fortified wall;
speaker: Narrator

text:
against all the ships of Tarshish
    and against all the highly prized vessels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The haughtiness of people shall be humbled,
    and the pride of everyone shall be brought low,
    and the Lord alone will be exalted on that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The idols shall utterly pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Enter the caves of the rocks
    and the holes of the ground,
from the terror of the Lord
    and from the glory of his majesty,
    when he rises to terrify the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day people will throw away
    to the moles and to the bats
their idols of silver and their idols of gold,
    which they made for themselves to worship,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to enter the caverns of the rocks
    and the clefts in the crags,
from the terror of the Lord
    and from the glory of his majesty,
    when he rises to terrify the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn away from mortals,
    who have only breath in their nostrils,
    for of what account are they?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts,
    is taking away from Jerusalem and from Judah
support and staff—
    all support of bread
    and all support of water—
speaker: Narrator

text:
warrior and soldier,
    judge and prophet,
    diviner and elder,
speaker: Narrator

text:
captain of fifty
    and dignitary,
counselor and skillful magician
    and expert enchanter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will make youths their princes,
    and children shall rule over them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people will be oppressed,
    everyone by another
    and everyone by a neighbor;
the youth will be insolent to the elder
    and the base to the honorable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Someone will seize a relative,
    a member of the clan, saying,
“You have a cloak;
    you shall be our leader,
and this heap of ruins
    shall be under your rule.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For Jerusalem has stumbled,
    and Judah has fallen,
because their speech and their deeds are against the Lord,
    defying his glorious presence.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Tell the innocent how fortunate they are,
    for they shall eat the fruit of their labors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to the guilty! How unfortunate they are,
    for what their hands have done shall be done to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people—their oppressors extort them,
    and creditors rule over them.
O my people, your leaders mislead you
    and confuse the course of your paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord rises to argue his case;
    he stands to judge the peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord enters into judgment
    with the elders and princes of his people:
It is you who have devoured the vineyard;
    the spoil of the poor is in your houses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you mean by crushing my people,
    by grinding the face of the poor? says the Lord God of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said:
Because the daughters of Zion are haughty
    and walk with outstretched necks,
    glancing wantonly with their eyes,
mincing along as they go,
    tinkling with their feet;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Lord will afflict with scabs
    the heads of the daughters of Zion,
    and the Lord will lay bare their scalps and heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will take away the finery of the anklets, the headbands, and the crescents;
speaker: Narrator

text: the pendants, the bracelets, and the scarfs;
speaker: Narrator

text: the headdresses, the armlets, the sashes, the perfume boxes, and the amulets;
speaker: Narrator

text: the signet rings and nose rings;
speaker: Narrator

text: the festal robes, the mantles, the cloaks, and the handbags;
speaker: Narrator

text: the garments of gauze, the linen garments, the turbans, and the veils.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Your men shall fall by the sword
    and your warriors in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And her gates shall lament and mourn;
    desolate, she shall sit upon the ground.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: On that day the branch of the Lord shall be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land shall be the pride and glory of the survivors of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who has been recorded for life in Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: once the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and cleansed the bloodstains of Jerusalem from its midst by a spirit of judgment and by a spirit of burning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord will create over the whole site of Mount Zion and over its places of assembly a cloud by day and smoke and the shining of a flaming fire by night. Indeed, over all the glory there will be a canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will serve as a pavilion, a shade by day from the heat and a refuge and a shelter from the storm and rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will sing for my beloved
    my love song concerning his vineyard:
My beloved had a vineyard
    on a very fertile hill.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And now, inhabitants of Jerusalem
    and people of Judah,
judge between me
    and my vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What more was there to do for my vineyard
    that I have not done in it?
When I expected it to yield grapes,
    why did it yield rotten grapes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now I will tell you
    what I will do to my vineyard.
I will remove its hedge,
    and it shall be devoured;
I will break down its wall,
    and it shall be trampled down.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts
    is the house of Israel,
and the people of Judah
    are his cherished garden;
he expected justice
    but saw bloodshed;
righteousness
    but heard a cry!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who join house to house,
    who add field to field,
until there is room for no one,
    and you are left to live alone
    in the midst of the land!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of hosts has sworn in my hearing:
Surely many houses shall be desolate,
    large and beautiful houses, without inhabitant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For ten acres of vineyard shall yield but one bath,
    and a homer of seed shall yield a mere ephah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who rise early in the morning
    in pursuit of strong drink,
who linger in the evening
    to be inflamed by wine,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose feasts consist of lyre and harp,
    tambourine and flute and wine,
but who do not regard the deeds of the Lord
    or see the work of his hands!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore Sheol has enlarged its appetite
    and opened its mouth beyond measure;
the nobility of Jerusalem and her multitude go down,
    her throng and all who exult in her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People are bowed down, everyone is brought low,
    and the eyes of the haughty are humbled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Lord of hosts is exalted by justice,
    and the Holy God shows himself holy by righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the lambs shall graze as in their pasture;
    fatted calves and kids shall feed among the ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who drag iniquity along with cords of falsehood,
    who drag sin along as with cart ropes,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Woe to those who call evil good
    and good evil,
who put darkness for light
    and light for darkness,
who put bitter for sweet
    and sweet for bitter!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes
    and shrewd in their own sight!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are heroes in drinking wine
    and valiant at mixing drink,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who acquit the guilty for a bribe
    and deprive the innocent of their rights!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, as the tongue of fire devours the stubble
    and as dry grass sinks down in the flame,
so their root will become rotten,
    and their blossom go up like dust,
for they have rejected the instruction of the Lord of hosts
    and have despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the anger of the Lord was kindled against his people,
    and he stretched out his hand against them and struck them;
    the mountains quaked,
and their corpses were like refuse
    in the streets.
For all this his anger has not turned away,
    and his hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will raise a signal for a nation far away
    and whistle for a people at the ends of the earth.
Here they come, swiftly, speedily!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
They will roar over it on that day,
    like the roaring of the sea.
And if one look to the land—
    only darkness and distress;
and the light grows dark with its clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, high and lofty, and the hem of his robe filled the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seraphs were in attendance above him; each had six wings: with two they covered their faces, and with two they covered their feet, and with two they flew.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: The pivots on the thresholds shook at the voices of those who called, and the house filled with smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, “Woe is me! I am lost, for I am a man of unclean lips, and I live among a people of unclean lips, yet my eyes have seen the King, the Lord of hosts!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the seraphs flew to me, holding a live coal that had been taken from the altar with a pair of tongs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seraph touched my mouth with it and said, “Now that this has touched your lips, your guilt has departed and your sin is blotted out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?” And I said, “Here am I; send me!”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Make the mind of this people dull,
    and stop their ears,
    and shut their eyes,
so that they may not look with their eyes
    and listen with their ears
and comprehend with their minds
    and turn and be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, “How long, O Lord?” And he said,
“Until cities lie waste
    without inhabitant,
and houses without people,
    and the land is utterly desolate;
speaker: Narrator

text:
until the Lord sends everyone far away,
    and vast is the emptiness in the midst of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if a tenth part remain in it,
    it will be burned again,
like a terebinth or an oak
    whose stump remains standing
    when it is felled.”
(The holy seed is its stump.)
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of Ahaz son of Jotham son of Uzziah, king of Judah, King Rezin of Aram and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel went up to attack Jerusalem but could not conquer it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the house of David heard that Aram had allied itself with Ephraim, the heart of Ahaz and the heart of his people shook as the trees of the forest shake before the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go out to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shear-jashub, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the fuller’s field,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say to him: Take heed, be quiet, do not fear, and do not let your heart be faint because of these two smoldering stumps of firebrands, because of the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram and the son of Remaliah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because Aram—with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah—has plotted evil against you, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Let us go up against Judah and terrify it and conquer it for ourselves and make the son of Tabeel king in it’;
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore thus says the Lord God:
It shall not stand,
    and it shall not come to pass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the head of Aram is Damascus,
    and the head of Damascus is Rezin.
(Within sixty-five years Ephraim will be shattered, no longer a people.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
The head of Ephraim is Samaria,
    and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah.
If you do not stand firm in faith,
    you shall not stand at all.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Lord spoke to Ahaz, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ask a sign of the Lord your God; let it be deep as Sheol or high as heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, and I will not put the Lord to the test.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah said, “Hear then, O house of David! Is it too little for you to weary mortals that you weary my God also?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Look, the young woman is with child and shall bear a son and shall name him Immanuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall eat curds and honey by the time he knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good.
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the child knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land before whose two kings you are in dread will be deserted.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will bring on you and on your people and on your ancestral house such days as have not come since the day that Ephraim departed from Judah—the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will whistle for the fly that is at the sources of the streams of Egypt and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they will all come and settle in the steep ravines and in the clefts of the rocks and on all the thornbushes and on all the watering holes.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will shave with a razor hired beyond the River—with the king of Assyria—the head and the hair of the feet, and it will take off the beard as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day one will keep alive a young cow and two sheep
speaker: Narrator

text: and will eat curds because of the abundance of milk that they give, for everyone left in the land shall eat curds and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day every place where there used to be a thousand vines, worth a thousand shekels of silver, will become briers and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: With bow and arrows one will go there, for all the land will be briers and thorns,
speaker: Narrator

text: and as for all the hills that used to be hoed with a hoe, you will not go there for fear of briers and thorns, but they will become a place where cattle are let loose and where sheep tread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Take a large tablet and write on it in common characters, ‘Belonging to Maher-shalal-hash-baz,’
speaker: Narrator

text: and have it attested for me by reliable witnesses, the priest Uriah and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord said to me, “Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz,
speaker: Narrator

text: for before the child knows how to call ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be carried away by the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to me again:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Because this people has refused the waters of Shiloah that flow gently and melt in fear before Rezin and the son of Remaliah,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore the Lord is bringing up against it the mighty flood waters of the River, the king of Assyria and all his glory; it will rise above all its channels and overflow all its banks;
speaker: Narrator

text: it will sweep on into Judah as a flood and, pouring over, will reach up to the neck, and its outspread wings will fill the breadth of your land, O Immanuel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: The Lord spoke thus to me while his hand was strong upon me and warned me not to walk in the way of this people, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not call conspiracy all that this people calls conspiracy, and do not fear what it fears or be in dread.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord of hosts, him you shall regard as holy; let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will become a sanctuary, a stone one strikes against; for both houses of Israel he will become a rock one stumbles over, a trap and a snare for the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And many among them shall stumble; they shall fall and be broken; they shall be snared and taken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bind up the testimony; seal the teaching among my disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will wait for the Lord, who is hiding his face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I and the children whom the Lord has given me are signs and portents in Israel from the Lord of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if people say to you, “Consult the ghosts and the familiar spirits that chirp and mutter; should not a people consult their gods, the dead on behalf of the living,
speaker: Narrator

text: for teaching and for instruction?” surely those who speak like this will have no dawn!
speaker: Narrator

text: They will pass through the land, greatly distressed and hungry; when they are hungry, they will be enraged and will curse their king and their gods. They will turn their faces upward,
speaker: Narrator

text: or they will look to the earth, but they will see only distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish, and they will be thrust into thick darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there will be no gloom for those who were in anguish. In the former time he brought into contempt the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but in the latter time he will make glorious the way of the sea, the land beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people who walked in darkness
    have seen a great light;
those who lived in a land of deep darkness—
    on them light has shined.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the yoke of their burden
    and the bar across their shoulders,
    the rod of their oppressor,
    you have broken as on the day of Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For all the boots of the tramping warriors
    and all the garments rolled in blood
    shall be burned as fuel for the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For a child has been born for us,
    a son given to us;
authority rests upon his shoulders,
    and he is named
Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God,
    Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Great will be his authority,
    and there shall be endless peace
for the throne of David and his kingdom.
    He will establish and uphold it
with justice and with righteousness
    from this time onward and forevermore.
The zeal of the Lord of hosts will do this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord sent a word against Jacob,
    and it fell on Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and all the people knew it—
    Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria—
    but in pride and arrogance of heart they said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The bricks have fallen,
    but we will build with dressed stones;
the sycamores have been cut down,
    but we will put cedars in their place.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the Lord raised adversaries against them
    and stirred up their enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Arameans on the east and the Philistines on the west,
    and they devoured Israel with open mouth.
For all this his anger has not turned away;
    his hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people did not turn to him who struck them
    or seek the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the Lord cut off from Israel head and tail,
    palm branch and reed in one day—
speaker: Narrator

text:
elders and dignitaries are the head,
    and prophets who teach lies are the tail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for those who led this people led them astray,
    and those who were led by them were left in confusion.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For wickedness burned like a fire,
    consuming briers and thorns;
it kindled the thickets of the forest,
    and they swirled upward in a column of smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Through the wrath of the Lord of hosts
    the land was burned,
and the people became like fuel for the fire;
    no one spared another.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Manasseh devoured Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh,
    and together they were against Judah.
For all this his anger has not turned away;
    his hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who make iniquitous decrees,
    who write oppressive statutes,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to turn aside the needy from justice
    and to rob the poor of my people of their right,
to make widows their spoil
    and to plunder orphans!
speaker: Narrator

text:
What will you do on the day of punishment,
    in the calamity that will come from far away?
To whom will you flee for help,
    and where will you leave your wealth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so as not to crouch among the prisoners
    or fall among the slain?
For all this his anger has not turned away;
    his hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to Assyria, the rod of my anger—
    the club in their hands is my fury!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Against a godless nation I send him,
    and against the people of my wrath I command him,
to take spoil and seize plunder,
    and to tread them down like the mire of the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But this is not what he intends,
    nor does he have this in mind,
but it is in his heart to destroy
    and to cut off nations not a few.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he says:
“Are not my commanders all kings?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not Calno like Carchemish?
    Is not Hamath like Arpad?
    Is not Samaria like Damascus?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As my hand has reached to the kingdoms of the idols
    whose images were greater than those of Jerusalem and Samaria,
speaker: Narrator

text:
shall I not do to Jerusalem and her idols
    what I have done to Samaria and her images?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord has finished all his work on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, he will punish the arrogant boasting of the king of Assyria and his haughty pride.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My hand has found, like a nest,
    the wealth of the peoples,
and as one gathers eggs that have been forsaken,
    so I have gathered all the earth,
and there was none that moved a wing
    or opened its mouth or chirped.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall the ax vaunt itself over the one who wields it
    or the saw magnify itself against the one who handles it?
As if a rod should raise the one who lifts it up,
    or as if a staff should lift the one who is not wood!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts,
    will send wasting sickness among his stout warriors,
and under his glory a burning will be kindled
    like the burning of fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The light of Israel will become a fire
    and his Holy One a flame,
and it will burn and devour
    his thorns and briers in one day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The glory of his forest and his fruitful land
    the Lord will destroy, both soul and body,
    and it will be as when an invalid wastes away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The remnant of the trees of his forest will be so few
    that a child can write them down.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the remnant of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will no longer lean on the one who struck them but will lean on the Lord, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: A remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For though your people, O Israel, were like the sand of the sea, only a remnant of them will return. Destruction is decreed, an overwhelming verdict.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord God of hosts will make a full end, as decreed, in all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore thus says the Lord God of hosts: “O my people who live in Zion, do not be afraid of the Assyrians when they beat you with a rod and lift up their staff against you as the Egyptians did.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in a very little while my indignation will come to an end, and my anger will be directed to their destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of hosts will wield a whip against them, as when he struck Midian at the rock of Oreb; his staff will be over the sea, and he will lift it as he did in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day his burden will be removed from your shoulder, and his yoke will be destroyed from your neck.
He has gone up from Samaria;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Cry aloud, O daughter Gallim!
    Listen, O Laishah!
    Answer her, O Anathoth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Madmenah is in flight;
    the inhabitants of Gebim flee for safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This very day he will halt at Nob;
    he will shake his fist
    at the mount of daughter Zion,
    the hill of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts,
    will lop the boughs with terrifying power;
the tallest trees will be cut down,
    and the lofty will be brought low.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will hack down the thickets of the forest with an ax,
    and Lebanon with its majestic trees will fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A shoot shall come out from the stump of Jesse,
    and a branch shall grow out of his roots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The spirit of the Lord shall rest on him,
    the spirit of wisdom and understanding,
    the spirit of counsel and might,
    the spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His delight shall be in the fear of the Lord.
He shall not judge by what his eyes see
    or decide by what his ears hear,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but with righteousness he shall judge for the poor
    and decide with equity for the oppressed of the earth;
he shall strike the earth with the rod of his mouth,
    and with the breath of his lips he shall kill the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteousness shall be the belt around his waist
    and faithfulness the belt around his loins.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The nursing child shall play over the hole of the asp,
    and the weaned child shall put its hand on the adder’s den.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will not hurt or destroy
    on all my holy mountain,
for the earth will be full of the knowledge of the Lord
    as the waters cover the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the root of Jesse shall stand as a signal to the peoples; the nations shall inquire of him, and his dwelling shall be glorious.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will again raise his hand to recover the remnant that is left of his people, from Assyria, from Egypt, from Pathros, from Cush, from Elam, from Shinar, from Hamath, and from the coastlands of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will raise a signal for the nations
    and will assemble the outcasts of Israel
and gather the dispersed of Judah
    from the four corners of the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But they shall swoop down on the backs of the Philistines in the west;
    together they shall plunder the people of the east.
They shall put forth their hand against Edom and Moab,
    and the Ammonites shall obey them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Lord will dry up
    the tongue of the sea of Egypt
and will wave his hand over the River
    with his scorching wind
and will split it into seven channels
    and make a way to cross on foot;
speaker: Narrator

text:
so there shall be a highway from Assyria
    for the remnant that is left of his people,
as there was for Israel
    when they came up from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will say on that day:
“I will give thanks to you, O Lord,
    for though you were angry with me,
your anger turned away,
    and you comforted me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Sing praises to the Lord, for he has done gloriously;
    let this be known in all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shout aloud and sing for joy, O royal Zion,
    for great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The oracle concerning Babylon that Isaiah son of Amoz saw.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I myself have commanded my consecrated ones,
    have summoned my warriors, my proudly exulting ones,
    to execute my anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, a tumult on the mountains
    as of a great multitude!
Listen, an uproar of kingdoms,
    of nations gathering together!
The Lord of hosts is mustering
    an army for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They come from a distant land,
    from the end of the heavens,
the Lord and the weapons of his indignation,
    to destroy the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wail, for the day of the Lord is near;
    it will come like destruction from the Almighty!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore all hands will be feeble,
    and every human heart will melt,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
See, the day of the Lord is coming,
    cruel, with wrath and fierce anger,
to make the earth a desolation
    and to destroy its sinners from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the stars of the heavens and their constellations
    will not give their light;
the sun will be dark at its rising,
    and the moon will not shed its light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will punish the world for its evil
    and the wicked for their iniquity;
I will put an end to the pride of the arrogant
    and lay low the insolence of tyrants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make mortals more rare than fine gold
    and humans than the gold of Ophir.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I will make the heavens tremble,
    and the earth will be shaken out of its place
at the wrath of the Lord of hosts
    in the day of his fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a gazelle on the run
    or like sheep with no one to gather them,
all will turn back to their own people,
    and all will flee to their own lands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is found will be thrust through,
    and whoever is caught will fall by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their infants will be dashed to pieces
    before their eyes;
their houses will be plundered
    and their wives raped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, I am stirring up the Medes against them,
    who have no regard for silver
    and do not delight in gold.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms,
    the splendor and pride of the Chaldeans,
will be like Sodom and Gomorrah
    when God overthrew them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But wild animals will lie down there,
    and its houses will be full of howling creatures;
there ostriches will live,
    and there goat-demons will dance.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: But the Lord will have compassion on Jacob and will again choose Israel and will settle them in their own land, and aliens will join them and attach themselves to the house of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the nations will take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will possess the nations as male and female slaves in the Lord’s land; they will take captive those who were their captors and rule over those who oppressed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord has given you rest from your pain and turmoil and the hard service with which you were made to serve,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon:
How the oppressor has ceased!
    How his insolence has ceased!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked,
    the scepter of rulers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that struck down the peoples in wrath
    with unceasing blows,
that ruled the nations in anger
    with unrelenting persecution.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The whole earth is at rest and quiet;
    they break forth into singing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The cypresses exult over you,
    the cedars of Lebanon, saying,
“Since you were laid low,
    no one comes to cut us down.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
All of them will speak
    and say to you:
“You, too, have become as weak as we!
    You have become like us!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your pomp is brought down to Sheol,
    and the sound of your harps;
maggots are the bed beneath you,
    and worms are your covering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How you are fallen from heaven,
    O Morning Star, son of Dawn!
How you are cut down to the ground,
    you who laid the nations low!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will ascend to the tops of the clouds;
    I will make myself like the Most High.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you are brought down to Sheol,
    to the depths of the Pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who see you will stare at you
    and ponder over you:
“Is this the man who made the earth tremble,
    who shook kingdoms,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who made the world like a desert
    and overthrew its cities,
    who would not let his prisoners go home?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the kings of the nations lie in glory,
    each in his own tomb,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but you are cast out, away from your grave,
    like loathsome carrion,
clothed with the dead, those pierced by the sword,
    who go down to the stones of the Pit
    like a corpse trampled underfoot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will not be joined with them in burial
    because you have destroyed your land;
    you have killed your people.
May the descendants of evildoers
    nevermore be named!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Prepare a place of slaughter for his sons
    because of the guilt of their father.
Let them never rise to possess the earth
    or cover the face of the world with cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will rise up against them, says the Lord of hosts, and will cut off from Babylon name and remnant, offspring and posterity, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will make it a possession of the screech owl and pools of water, and I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, says the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of hosts has sworn:
As I have designed,
    so shall it be,
and as I have planned,
    so shall it come to pass:
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will break the Assyrian in my land
    and on my mountains trample him under foot;
his yoke shall be removed from them
    and his burden from their shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the plan that is planned
    concerning the whole earth,
and this is the hand that is stretched out
    over all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord of hosts has planned,
    and who will annul it?
His hand is stretched out,
    and who will turn it back?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that King Ahaz died this oracle came:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not rejoice, all you Philistines,
    that the rod that struck you is broken,
for from the root of the snake will come forth an adder,
    and its fruit will be a flying fiery serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In my pastures the poor will graze
    and the needy lie down in safety,
but I will make your root die of famine,
    and your remnant I will kill.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wail, O gate; cry, O city;
    melt in fear, O Philistia, all of you!
For smoke comes out of the north,
    and there is no straggler in its ranks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What will one answer the messengers of the nation?
“The Lord has founded Zion,
    and the needy among his people
    will find refuge in her.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
An oracle concerning Moab.
Because Ar is laid waste in a night,
    Moab is undone;
because Kir is laid waste in a night,
    Moab is undone.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore the abundance they have gained
    and what they have laid up
they carry away
    over the Wadi of the Willows.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the waters of Dibon are full of blood,
    yet I will bring upon Dibon even more—
a lion for those of Moab who escape,
    for the remnant of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Send lambs
    to the ruler of the land,
from Sela, by way of the desert,
    to the mount of daughter Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like fluttering birds,
    like scattered nestlings,
so are the daughters of Moab
    at the fords of the Arnon.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
let the outcasts of Moab
    settle among you;
be a refuge to them
    from the destroyer.”
When the oppressor is no more,
    and destruction has ceased,
and marauders have vanished from the land,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then a throne shall be established in steadfast love
    in the tent of David,
    and on it shall sit in faithfulness
a ruler who seeks justice
    and is swift to do what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have heard of the pride of Moab
    —how proud he is!—
of his arrogance, his pride, and his insolence;
    his boasts are false.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore let Moab wail;
    let everyone wail for Moab.
Mourn, utterly stricken,
    for the raisin cakes of Kir-hareseth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the fields of Heshbon languish,
    and the vines of Sibmah,
whose clusters once made drunk
    the lords of the nations,
reached to Jazer
    and strayed to the desert;
their shoots once spread abroad
    and crossed over the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I weep as Jazer weeps
    for the vines of Sibmah;
I drench you with my tears,
    O Heshbon and Elealeh,
for the shout over your fruit harvest
    and your grain harvest has ceased.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore my heart moans like a harp for Moab
    and my very soul for Kir-heres.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moab presents himself, when he wearies himself upon the high place, when he comes to his sanctuary to pray, he will not prevail.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the word that the Lord spoke concerning Moab in the past.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the Lord says, “In three years, like the years of a hired worker, the glory of Moab will be brought into contempt, in spite of all its great multitude, and those who survive will be very few and feeble.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
An oracle concerning Damascus.
See, Damascus will cease to be a city
    and will become a heap of ruins.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The fortress will disappear from Ephraim
    and the kingdom from Damascus,
and the remnant of Aram will be
    like the glory of the people of Israel,
            says the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day
    the glory of Jacob will be brought low,
    and the fat of his flesh will grow lean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And it shall be as when reapers gather standing grain
    and their arms harvest the ears,
and as when one gleans the ears of grain
    in the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gleanings will be left in it,
    as when an olive tree is beaten—
two or three berries
    in the top of the highest bough,
four or five
    on the branches of a fruit tree,
            says the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day people will look to their Maker, with their eyes on the Holy One of Israel;
speaker: Narrator

text: they will not have regard for the altars, the work of their hands, and they will not look to what their own fingers have made, either the sacred poles or the altars of incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day their fortified cities will be like the deserted places of the Hivites and the Amorites, which they deserted because of the people of Israel, and there will be desolation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have forgotten God your Savior
    and have not remembered the Rock of your refuge;
therefore, though you plant pleasant gardens
    and set out branches of a foreign god,
speaker: Narrator

text:
though you make them grow on the day that you plant them
    and make them blossom in the morning that you sow,
yet the harvest will flee away
    in a day of sickness and incurable pain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe, the thunder of many peoples,
    they thunder like the thundering of the sea!
The roar of nations,
    they roar like the roaring of mighty waters!
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the nations roar like the roaring of many waters,
    he will rebuke them, and they will flee far away,
chased like chaff on the mountains before the wind
    and like whirling dust before the storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At evening time, sudden terror!
    Before morning, they are no more.
This is the fate of those who despoil us
    and the lot of those who plunder us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe, land of buzzing wings
    beyond the rivers of Cush,
speaker: Narrator

text:
sending ambassadors by the Nile
    in vessels of papyrus on the waters!
Go, you swift messengers,
    to a nation tall and smooth,
to a people feared near and far,
    a nation mighty and conquering,
    whose land the rivers divide.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All you inhabitants of the world,
    you who live on the earth,
when a signal is raised on the mountains, look!
    When a trumpet is blown, listen!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For thus the Lord said to me:
“I will quietly look from my dwelling
    like clear heat in sunshine,
    like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For before the harvest, when the blossom is over
    and the flower becomes a ripening grape,
he will cut off the shoots with pruning hooks,
    and the spreading branches he will hew away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall all be left
    to the birds of prey of the mountains
    and to the animals of the earth.
And the birds of prey will summer on them,
    and all the animals of the earth will winter on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time gifts will be brought to the Lord of hosts from a people tall and smooth, from a people feared near and far, a nation mighty and conquering, whose land the rivers divide, to Mount Zion, the place of the name of the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An oracle concerning Egypt.
See, the Lord is riding on a swift cloud
    and comes to Egypt;
the idols of Egypt will tremble at his presence,
    and the heart of the Egyptians will melt within them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will stir up Egyptians against Egyptians,
    and they will fight, one against the other,
    neighbor against neighbor,
    city against city, kingdom against kingdom;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will deliver the Egyptians
    into the hand of a hard master;
a fierce king will rule over them,
    says the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters of the Nile will be dried up,
    and the river will be parched and dry;
speaker: Narrator

text:
its canals will become foul,
    and the branches of Egypt’s Nile will diminish and dry up.
Reeds and rushes will rot away,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The workers in flax will be in despair,
    and the carders and those at the loom will grow pale.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its weavers will be dismayed,
    and all who work for wages will be grieved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Clearly the princes of Zoan are foolish;
    the wise counselors of Pharaoh give stupid counsel.
How can you say to Pharaoh,
    “I am one of the sages,
    a descendant of ancient kings”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where now are your sages?
    Let them tell you and make known
    what the Lord of hosts has planned against Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The princes of Zoan have become fools,
    and the princes of Memphis are deluded;
those who are the cornerstones of its tribes
    have led Egypt astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has poured into them
    a spirit of confusion;
and they have made Egypt stagger in all its doings
    as a drunkard staggers around in his vomit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Neither head nor tail, palm branch or reed,
    will be able to do anything for Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Egyptians will be like women and tremble with fear before the hand that the Lord of hosts raises against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the land of Judah will become a terror to the Egyptians; everyone to whom it is mentioned will fear because of the plan that the Lord of hosts is planning against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day there will be five cities in the land of Egypt that speak the language of Canaan and swear allegiance to the Lord of hosts. One of these will be called the City of the Sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the midst of the land of Egypt and a pillar to the Lord at its border.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a sign and a witness to the Lord of hosts in the land of Egypt; when they cry to the Lord because of oppressors, he will send them a savior and will defend and deliver them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will make himself known to the Egyptians, and the Egyptians will know the Lord on that day and will serve with sacrifice and offerings, and they will make vows to the Lord and perform them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike Egypt, striking but healing, so that they will return to the Lord, and he will listen to their supplications and heal them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrian will come into Egypt and the Egyptian into Assyria, and the Egyptians will serve with the Assyrians.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day Israel will be the third party with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: whom the Lord of hosts has blessed, saying, “Blessed be Egypt my people and Assyria the work of my hands and Israel my heritage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that the commander-in-chief, who was sent by King Sargon of Assyria, came to Ashdod and fought against it and took it—
speaker: Narrator

text: at that time the Lord had spoken to Isaiah son of Amoz, saying, “Go and loose the sackcloth from your loins and take your sandals off your feet,” and he had done so, walking naked and barefoot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Just as my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and a portent against Egypt and Cush,
speaker: Narrator

text: so shall the king of Assyria lead away the Egyptians as captives and the Cushites as exiles, both the young and the old, naked and barefoot, with buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall be dismayed and confounded because of Cush their hope and of Egypt their boast.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the inhabitants of this coastland will say, ‘See, this is what has happened to those in whom we hoped and to whom we fled for help and deliverance from the king of Assyria! And we, how shall we escape?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oracle concerning the wilderness of the sea.
As whirlwinds in the Negeb sweep on,
    it comes from the desert,
    from a terrible land.

text: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Assyria sent the Rabshakeh with a great army from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. He stood by the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the fuller’s field.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there came out to him Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Rabshakeh said to them, “Say to Hezekiah: Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: On what do you base this reliance of yours?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you think that mere words are strategy and power for war? On whom, then, do you now rely, that you have rebelled against me?
speaker: Narrator

text: See, you are relying on Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of anyone who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who rely on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you say to me, ‘We rely on the Lord our God,’ is it not he whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, ‘You shall worship before this altar’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able on your part to set riders on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: How then can you repulse a single captain among the least of my master’s servants, when you rely on Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, is it without the Lord that I have come up against this land to destroy it? The Lord said to me, Go up against this land, and destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the Rabshakeh, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it; do not speak to us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Rabshakeh said, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you and not to the people sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and drink their own urine?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah, “Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the king: Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let Hezekiah make you rely on the Lord by saying, ‘The Lord will surely deliver us; this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not listen to Hezekiah, for thus says the king of Assyria: Make your peace with me and come out to me; then every one of you will eat from your own vine and your own fig tree and drink water from your own cistern,
speaker: Narrator

text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let Hezekiah mislead you by saying, ‘The Lord will deliver us.’ Has any of the gods of the nations delivered their land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who among all the gods of these countries have delivered their countries out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, “Do not answer him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.

text: When King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth and went into the house of the Lord.

text: And he sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.

text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah: This day is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace; children have come to the birth, and there is no strength to bring them forth.

text: It may be that the Lord your God heard the words of the Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words that the Lord your God has heard; therefore lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.”

text: When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,

text: Isaiah said to them, “Say to your master: Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid because of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have reviled me.

text: I myself will put a spirit in him, so that he shall hear a rumor and return to his own land; I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.”

text: The Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, for he had heard that the king had left Lachish.

text: “Thus shall you speak to King Hezekiah of Judah: Do not let your God on whom you rely deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.

text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them, the nations that my predecessors destroyed, Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?

text: “O Lord of hosts, God of Israel, who are enthroned above the cherubim, you are God, you alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth; you have made heaven and earth.

text: “Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not come into this city, shoot an arrow there, come before it with a shield, or cast up a siege ramp against it.

text: As he was worshiping in the house of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with the sword, and they escaped into the land of Ararat. His son Esar-haddon succeeded him.

text: In those days Hezekiah became sick and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came to him and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order, for you shall die; you shall not recover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember now, O Lord, I implore you, how I have walked before you in faithfulness with a whole heart and have done what is good in your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and say to Hezekiah, Thus says the Lord, the God of your ancestor David: I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears; I will add fifteen years to your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria and defend this city.

text: “This is the sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do this thing that he has promised:

text: At that time King Merodach-baladan son of Baladan of Babylon sent envoys with letters and a present to Hezekiah, for he heard that he had been sick and had recovered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah welcomed them; he showed them his treasure house, the silver, the gold, the spices, the precious oil, his whole armory, all that was found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his house or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and said to him, “What did these men say? From where did they come to you?” Hezekiah answered, “They have come to me from a far country, from Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What have they seen in your house?” Hezekiah answered, “They have seen all that is in my house; there is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord of hosts:
speaker: Narrator

text: Days are coming when all that is in your house and that which your ancestors have stored up until this day shall be carried to Babylon; nothing shall be left, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of your own sons who are born to you shall be taken away; they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “There will be peace and security in my days.”
